Award.AwardTitle: Ab initio Based Multiscale Modeling of Thermal Transport in Femtosecond Laser Materials Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1336111
Zhang

The most striking feature of femtosecond laser that has not been matched by any other material processing means is its ability to remove material with minimal collateral damage. The objective of this project is to perform Ab initio based multiscale modeling of thermal transport in femtosecond laser materials processing. The key challenge in the modeling is to establish a unified formulation that can correctly and effectively describe thermal transport in femtosecond laser materials processing without or with minimal empirical formulations. The Ab initio based multiscale approach can bridge the divide between the experiments and theories, and eliminate the needs of any assumption and empirical parameters. A quantum molecular dynamics (MD) simulation based on density function theory (DFT) will be carried out first to determine appropriate intermolecular potentials for classical MD simulation. A hybrid MD/semi-classical two-temperature multiscale model will be developed by combining classical MD simulation based on the intermolecular potentials obtained from quantum MD simulation together with the semi-classical energy equation for electrons. An inverse heat transfer modeling based on the semi-classical two-temperature model will be carried out to obtain the microscale transport properties, which are then used to develop the continuum model for materials removal. The stochastic modeling of femtosecond laser processing of metal under uncertainties of thermophysical and processing parameters will be carried out. Experiments on femtosecond laser processing of gold and copper by femtosecond laser pulses will be conducted in order to validate the Ab initial based multiscale and stochastic models developed under this project.

The Ab initio based multiscale and stochastic models will allow the users to select proper processing parameters to obtain the desired micro- and nanostructure; this will result in significant reduction of cost associated with the traditional trial-and-error approach and will increase the economic competitiveness of the United States on nanomanufacturing. The outcome of the research will be disseminated through publications in archival journals, presentations at national and international conferences, and student dissertations. The outreach activities will also help promoting the public awareness and recognition of science and engineering and promote the public image of scientists and engineers, which will play a very important role in education at all levels and will also have broader impacts on technology, economy, and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most striking feature of femtosecond laser that has not been matched by any other material processing means is its ability to remove material with minimal collateral damage. The objective of this project was to perform ab initio based multiscale modeling of thermal transport in femtosecond laser materials processing. The Ab initio based multiscale approach can bridge the divide between the experiments and theories, and eliminate the needs of any assumption and empirical parameters.

A multiscale framework ranging from quantum mechanical (QM) determination of the electron temperature dependent thermodynamic properties, to the classical molecular dynamics (MD) coupling with the two temperature model (TTM) has been established. The multiscale framework named as QM-MM-TTM has general applicability to the femtosecond laser processing of metals. With the help of the high accuracy of ab initio determined electron thermophysical parameters, the QM-MD-TTM integrated framework paves a novel way to investigate the femtosecond laser interaction with metals from the perspective of multiscale simulation. The developed simulation tools based on hybrid quantum/classical molecular dynamics (MD) and two-temperature models have been used to study femtosecond laser interaction with different materials and the behaviors different materials under femtosecond laser interaction have been studied systematically.

As a result of the experimental effort, we discovered a universal mechanism of the ultrafast laser interactions with non-metal surfaces that explains major phenomena of ultrafast laser-surface interactions including formation of laser-induced periodic surface structures (LIPSS) for a broad range of laser parameters. The proposed mechanism of the ultrafast laser-surface interactions is not covered by the currently available theoretical models and requires a novel model. That is, our findings stimulate novel theoretical and simulation developments in the field of basic mechanisms of laser-semiconductor interactions. A method of obtaining highly regular LIPSS on semiconductor surfaces has been developed and demonstrated.

The research findings were disseminated by publication to archival journals, presentation to the professional conferences, and students' thesis. The PIs integrated the research funding to the undergraduate senior and graduate courses. The project helped the three graduate students, including one women, who worked on the project get the deep understanding of the multiscale modeling and experiments of femtosecond laser materials processing. The QM-MD-TTM integrated framework paves a novel way to investigate the femtosecond laser interaction with metals from the perspective of multiscale simulation. A universal mechanism of the ultrafast laser interactions with non-metal surfaces that, in particular, produces the specific high-intensity highly regular Laser-induced periodic surface structures (LIPSS). The research from this project can have significant impact on performances of solar cells, biological and chemical plasmonic sensors, and for multiple biomedical applications, e.g., regular nanostructuring of dental and surgical implants. A highly fruitful international collaboration has been established with two leading European groups working in the field of ultrafast laser-solid interactions.


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Yuwen Zhang

The multiscale framework named as QM-MM-TTM has general applicability to the femtosecond laser processing of metals. With the help of the high accuracy of ab initio determined electron thermophysical parameters, the QM-MD-TTM integrated framework paves a novel way to investigate the femtosecond laser interaction with metals from the perspective of multiscale simulation. The developed simulation tools based on hybrid quantum/classical molecular dynamics (MD) and two-temperature models have been used to study femtosecond laser interaction with different materials and the behaviors different materials under femtosecond laser interaction have been studied systematically. As a result of the experimental effort, we discovered a universal mechanism of the ultrafast laser interactions with non-metal surfaces that explains major phenomena of ultrafast laser-surface interactions including formation of laser-induced periodic surface structures (LIPSS) for a broad range of laser parameters. The PIs integrated the research funding to the undergraduate senior and graduate courses. The project helped the three graduate students, including one women, who worked on the project get the deep understanding of the multiscale modeling and experiments of femtosecond laser materials processing. The QM-MD-TTM integrated framework paves a novel way to investigate the femtosecond laser interaction with metals from the perspective of multiscale simulation. A universal mechanism of the ultrafast laser interactions with non-metal surfaces that, in particular, produces the specific high-intensity highly regular Laser-induced periodic surface structures (LIPSS). A highly fruitful international collaboration has been established with two leading European groups working in the field of ultrafast laser-solid interactions.
